conclusion: The radar emits waves that last 1μs each, with a time interval of 100μs between emissions. The sharp triangular waves on the screen represent reflections. The speed of light c = 3.0×10^8 m/s, and ab = bc in the diagram.
The diagram shows three triangular peaks on the screen, with points a, b, and c marked on the horizontal axis.
The relation ab = bc indicates that the time intervals between reflections are equal.
The points a, b, and c likely represent the times when reflections from obstacles are detected.
The equally spaced reflections suggest multiple reflections of the same signal bouncing back and forth between the radar and the obstacle.
For the first reflection (point a), the radio wave travels a distance of 2d (to the obstacle and back), with time = 2d/c.
For the second reflection (point b), the radio wave travels a distance of 4d (to the obstacle, back to the radar, to the obstacle again, and back to the radar), with time = 4d/c.
For the third reflection (point c), the radio wave travels a distance of 6d, with time = 6d/c.
Using the relationship ab = bc, the time between the first and second reflection equals the time between the second and third reflection, confirming the model.
Since ab = bc represents the time it takes for the wave to travel a distance of 2d, we have ab = 2d/c.
The interval between emissions is 100μs, and the peaks are equally spaced, so each interval (ab or bc) must be 100μs.
Using the equation 100×10^-6 s = 2d/c, we calculate d = (100×10^-6 s × c)/2.
The distance between the obstacle and the radar is 15 km.
